subject: Re: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: ... I d call that inappropriate.. using patterns for the sake of using patterns.. and likely in the contest of BDUF, right?  Have you read Joshua Kerievsky s
messageBody:
On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 11:20, Berin Loritsch wrote:
> Dave Astels wrote:
> > On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 10:33, Berin Loritsch wrote:
> >
> >
> >>There are antipatterns you have to beware of as well, one such
> >>antipattern is an overuse of patterns.
> >
> >
> > I wouldn't say that. the "inappropriate use of patterns", the
> > "too-early use of patterns", but overuse? That's pretty subjective.
>
> Ok. I can buy that. Of course I have worked on small to medium
> projects that tried to incorporate almost every pattern under the
> sun--many times causing more bulk than necessary. That is why I
> termed it "overuse", although "inappropreate use" applies better.

I'd call that inappropriate.. using patterns for the sake of using
patterns.. and likely in the contest of BDUF, right? Have you read
Joshua Kerievsky's "Refactoring to Patterns"? It explores/catalogs
refactorings that move you to/toward patterns.

> >>The TestCase is taken, and by reflection is turned into a TestSuite. So
> >>is it a TestCase or a TestSuite? That is an important distinction.
> >>The Model is not readily apparent. A stable and predictable model is
> >>essential to good design--esp. in this case. I have no problem with
> >>saying that a TestCollector dynamically creates a TestSuite from a
> >>collection of TestCases. That is understandable. I do have a problem
> >>with the TestCase being treated as a TestSuite though.
> >
> >
> > OK, I'll try to address this one.
> >
> > TestCase is a mechanism to allow fixture reuse. An instance of a
> > TestCase builds a fixture, runs a single test, and tears down the
> > fixture. By allowing TestCase to contain multiple tests (i.e. public
> > void testXXX() methods) you can share a fixture definition.
> >
> > Put another way, TestCase is NOT a way to conceptually group tests.
> > Each TestCase subclass represents a fixture, and contains a group of
> > tests that run in the context of that fixture. Once you realize this,
> > you'll find yourself switching (as I did some time ago) from having a
> > TestCase for each class you are testing (with a overly generic fixture
> > of which pieces were used by the different tests) to organizing tests
> > around the fixtures, with less regard for the classes being tested by
> > each TestCase.
>
> I tend to test interfaces. As such, with the current implementation of
> JUinit, I have one Abstract testcase to excersize the interface's
> contracts. I have concrete classes that extend that abstract test case
> for the individual classes. If there are specific issues or features
> of an implementation that need to be tested (i.e. consequences that
> are outside of the scope of the interface like ensuring temporary files
> are in the right place) I add new methods to the concrete test to ensure
> that things are done properly.

That sounds like a reasonable approach reasonable. It's a case of
extracting commonality to a superclass.

> As to what you are referring to as a Fixture, I am not exactly sure.

A fixture is the situation in which a test expects to run.
Specifically, it's what setUp() builds.

> > TestSuite is a mechanism for grouping a collection of TestCase instances
> > and running them sequentially. So, TestCase has the ability to create a
> > TestSuite containing all instances of itself (using reflection to create
> > an instance for each constituent test). Also, you have the ability to
> > create explicit TestSuites by subclassing TestSuite and writing a custom
> > suite() method. This is useful for collecting together groups of
> > smaller TestSuites which can be other custom TestSuites, or TestSuites
> > generated by TestCases.
>
> That's the thing. The TestSuite, while theorhetically a nice feature,
> adds too much. You also run the risk/temptation to write tests that
> require to be run in a specific order to pass. If the order is changed,
> or unpredictable, you have to write more robust tests.

All tools involve a certain amount of risk and/or temptation. It's a
matter of using it properly.

> Nine times out of ten, all you really need is a TestCollector. The
> collector finds all your tests, and runs them.

Very true. And that's easy enough to write. In fact there's
RecursiveTestSuite by Mike Bowler (http://gsbase.sourceforge.net) that
does that.

> > Both TestSuite and TestCase implement the Test interface. The
> > TestRunners work with things that are Tests, hence we can point at any
> > Test (ie TestSuite or TestCase) and recursively run all the contained
> > tests. The internal nodes are TestSuites and the leaves are TestCases.
>
>
> Yes, but what happens if you don't want to extend either TestCase or
> TestSuite? What happens if you want to access Assert from TestSuite?
> The contracts are with the *implementations* of the Test interface,
> and not with the Test interface itself.

You can always just implement Test and use Assert.

> > I hope that makes things clearer.
>
> What about the other points I had?

I only said I'd address that one :-)

Why not rewrite JUnit the way you are envisioning and see how it works &
how people like it? Nobody said you *HAVE* to use JUnit.
